thread.title: U.K.’s Whitbread to Spin Off Costa Coffee Chain

author: Nina Trentmann
title: U.K.’s Whitbread to Spin Off Costa Coffee Chain
text:
1 COMMENTS British hospitality group Whitbread WTB 1.92% PLC will spin off its Costa coffee chain amid mounting pressure from activist investors.
The group’s announcement Wednesday comes after investors, including activist funds Elliott Management Corp. and Sachem Head Capital Management LP which together hold a roughly 10% stake in Whitbread, have demanded wide-ranging changes.
More
More Companies Are Selling Assets to Raise Cash for Growth April 24, 2018 Volkswagen Plans First U.S. Bond Sale After Emissions Scandal April 23, 2018 Volkswagen’s Potential CEO Change Won’t Impact CFO April 10, 2018 The group said the split that will see it keep its Premier Inn hotel brand while Costa becomes a separate listed entity was part of its growth strategy for the business.
“The separation helps us focus,” said Whitbread’s Finance Director Nicholas Cadbury in an interview with CFO Journal. “Both businesses have such good growth opportunities that separating is best for them.”
Costa is the largest operator of coffee shops in the U.K. with 2,422 outlets as of March 1. It has a strong overseas presence, including China where it plans to have 1,200 outlets by 2022. Hotel chain Premier Inn—operating 72,466 rooms in the U.K.—recently acquired 19 hotels in Germany, comprising 3,100 rooms.
“We need more expertise in Premier Inn to focus on Germany and in Costa to concentrate on China,” said Mr. Cadbury.
Whitbread has followed this blueprint before. It previously owned the U.K. franchise of restaurant operator TGI Friday’s Inc., David Lloyd Leisure Ltd. health clubs, a number of Marriott International Inc. hotels and a stake in Britvic PLC, a soft-drink maker. “We have a history of buying companies, growing them and selling them again,” Mr. Cadbury said.
Elliott’s management said “it is pleased that Whitbread has announced a demerger,” adding the break up should be done within six months.
Newsletter Sign-up The company will likely take longer to complete the Costa spinoff, as the group is in the middle of a £100 million ($139.4 million) cost-saving exercise to offset higher inflation. That program is set to conclude in 2020. “It is important that we get these additional efficiencies before the demerger,” Mr. Cadbury said. The company is working with over 2,000 suppliers to reach its cost-savings target, he said.
It is too early to tell what impact the demerger will have on Whitbread’s finances, Mr. Cadbury said. Roughly 1,000 of the group’s employees work for both Premier Inn and Costa, and will be given a choice to transfer to the new unit, Mr. Cadbury said.
Whitbread on Wednesday reported a pretax profit of £548.4 million for the financial year ended March 1, compared with £515.4 million the year before. Revenues rose to £3.30 billion from £3.11 billion.
